summary: Henry F. Graff was a member of the Assassination Records Review Board (ARRB). The documents mention him in the context of the ARRB's work to declassify and release records related to the JFK assassination. He is mentioned in a document providing biographical information for the ARRB members. His role was to review and declassify assassination-related documents, ensuring compliance with the JFK Act. The documents highlight the ARRB's interactions with the CIA regarding the release of information, the protection of covert employee identities, and the declassification of military records related to U.S. policy toward Cuba. The documents span from 1995 to 1998, reflecting the period of the ARRB's active work.
significance: Henry F. Graff's significance lies in his role as a member of the Assassination Records Review Board (ARRB), which was responsible for the declassification and release of JFK assassination records. His involvement was crucial in ensuring transparency and compliance with the JFK Act, contributing to the public's understanding of the events surrounding the assassination.
